HK  delegates  urge  opposition  lawmakers  to  stop  malicious  acts. Hong  Kong  deputies  to  the  NPC  and  CPPCC  threw  their  weight  behind  central  authorities'  expression  of  concerns  about  the  deadlock  of  the  city's  LegCo.

LegCo  approves  HK$137.5b  epidemic  relief  fund. CE  Carrie  Lam  welcomed  the  passage  of  the  funding  application  for  the  second  round  of  relief  measures  to  offset  the  economic  impact  of  the  pandemic.

Community  leaders,  legal  experts  support  police  action. Community  leaders  and  legal  experts  have  voiced  support  for  the  arrests  of  prominent  public  figures  for  their  roles  in  unlawful  assemblies  last  year.

HK  sees  2  imported  cases  as  infection  tally  rises  to  1,023. The  government  said  it  would  close  down  the  coronavirus  testing  center  near  the  airport  because  of  the  sharp  fall  in  passenger  arrivals.

HK:  More  than  10  public  figures  held  over  illegal  assemblies. Local  media  reports  said  among  those  arrested  are  businessman  Jimmy  Lai,  politician  Leung  Kwok-hung  and  other  opposition  leaders,  including  Martin  Lee.

Liaison  office:  Opposition  distorting  Basic  Law. The  remarks  came  after  the  LegCo's  House  Committee  failed  to  elect  a  chair  at  its  15th  meeting  due  to  the  opposition  camp's  filibustering.

Cathay  Pacific  to  lay  off  overseas  cabin  crew,  furlough  pilots. In  a  statement,  Cathay  said  it  was  communicating  with  the  affected  crew  in  New  York,  San  Francisco  and  Los  Angeles  as  well  as  their  union.
China  Daily's  PolyU  coverage  wins  World  Press  Photo  nods. A  China  Daily  journalist  has  been  honored  with  two  awards  at  the  World  Press  Photo  contest.

MPF  records  large  losses  amid  pandemic. The  Mandatory  Provident  Fund  recorded  almost  HK$26,000  in  losses  per  person  on  average  from  January  to  mid-April,  according  to  a  MPF  consultancy.

Kwok  in  the  firing  line  as  LegCo  impasse  continues. Dennis  Kwok  Wing-hang  and  other  opposition  lawmakers  urged  to  stop  filibustering  in  the  legislature  and  to  start  scrutinizing  backlog  of  bills,  as  clock  ticks  before  prorogation  while  the  House  Committee  failed  to  elect  a  chairman  for  the  15th  time.

LegCo  head  regrets  House  Committee's  failure  to  elect  chair  again. LegCo  President  Andrew  Leung  has  expressed  deep  disappointment  and  regret  that  a  chairperson  was  still  not  elected  after  15  meetings.
Public  cooperation  urged  as  HK  sees  4  new  COVID-19  cases. The  latest  patients  are  all  returnees  from  the  United  Kingdom.

Justice  chief  says  HK's  judicial  independence  well  protected. Teresa  Cheng  said  that  judicial  independence  in  HK  is  well  protected  by  the  Basic  Law  and  urged  the  public  not  to  be  misled  by  speculative  reports.

HKMA:  SMEs  can  defer  loan  payments  May-Oct. Hong  Kong’s  small  and  medium-sized  companies  can  defer  their  principal  loan  payments  between  May  1  and  Oct  31,  the  Hong  Kong  Monetary  Authority  said  in  a  statement.

Repair  cost  for  wrecked  PolyU  campus  'estimated  at  HK$700b'. Hong  Kong  Polytechnic  University  expects  the  costs  of  repairing  campus  facilities  damaged  by  rioters  could  reach  US$90  million.

China  Daily's  PolyU  coverage  wins  World  Press  Photo  nods. The  video,  "Battleground  Poly  U",  by  multimedia  journalist  DJ  Clark  was  named  best  interactive  visual  experience  and  outstanding  immersive  experience.

Hong  Kong  co-working  thrives  as  S'pore  struggles  in  shutdown. The  Executive  Centre,  a  high-end  serviced-office  operator,  leased  33%  more  desk  space  in  the  first  quarter  in  Hong  Kong  than  a  year  earlier.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.56%  higher. The  Hang  Seng  Index  gained  373.55  points  to  close  at  24,380.0  points  on  Friday.

Obstruction  of  legislature  must  stop. A  spokesperson  for  the  Commissioner's  Office  said  it  is  "natural  and  dutiful"  for  two  central  govt  bodies  on  HK  affairs  to  comment  on  the  current  LegCo  impasse.
Teachers,  students  worried  as  schools  remain  in  limbo. Students  said  that  online  learning  is  weakening  their  ability  to  get  an  adequate  grasp  of  some  subjects.

Hong  Kong  man  jailed  for  operating  bar  amid  ban. A  bar  owner  in  HK’s  Tsim  Sha  Tsui  neighborhood  was  jailed  for  a  week  and  is  the  first  to  be  convicted  of  violating  govt-mandated  business  closures.

Cathay's  passenger  traffic  1%  of  usual  after  'drastic'  drop. Cathay  Pacific  expects  lower  than  1,000  passengers  per  day  this  month  compared  with  the  usual  100,000  as  it  operates  at  just  3%  of  normal  capacity.

DSE  arrangements  seen  as  'acceptable'  and  'thoughtful'. Secondary  school  principals  and  senior  students  sitting  this  year's  HKDSE  examination  praised  new  arrangements  as  "acceptable"  and  "thoughtful".

HK  sees  1  new  infection,  lowest  single-day  figure  in  38  days. Hong  Kong  recorded  just  one  new  COVID-19  case  on  Thursday,  the  lowest  daily  count  since  March  9,  bringing  the  local  tally  to  1,017.

Education  secretary:  Uncertain  when  schools  will  reopen  in  HK. Schools  will  resume  classes  only  when  they  are  fully  prepared  for  this  and  the  market  has  enough  stock  of  protective  gear,  the  city’s  education  secretary  said.

Commissioner's  Office  backs  comments  by  central  govt  bodies. A  spokesperson  said  it  was  "only  right  and  proper"  that  the  HKMAO  and  Liaison  Office  had  commented  on  the  current  deadlock  in  the  city's  legislature.
Hong  Kong  shares  close  0.58%  lower. The  Hang  Seng  Index  lost  138.89  points  to  close  at  24,006.45  points  on  Thursday.

HK  political  leaders  call  for  legislation  to  enact  Article  23. The  call  issued  by  political  leaders  in  Hong  Kong  came  as  the  city  held  a  series  of  online  events  to  mark  the  5th  National  Security  Education  Day.

Nation's  blockchain  drive  a  boon  for  Hong  Kong. Besides  the  traditional  financial  services  industry  —  one  of  the  pillars  of  the  Hong  Kong  economy  —  blockchain  has  more  to  offer  and  make  a  difference.

Young  HK  entrepreneur  helps  motherland  produce  masks. Hong  Kong  entrepreneur  Jack  Lam  is  considering  setting  up  a  venture  fund  to  help  young  entrepreneurs  from  HK  and  Macao  expand  their  businesses.
COVID-19  control  vital  to  national  security. Medical  experts  appealed  to  Hong  Kong  people  on  Wednesday  to  safeguard  national  security  by  remaining  vigilant  against  COVID-19.

HK  must  not  be  the  weak  link  of  national  security. Luo  Huining,  director  of  the  Liaison  Office,  said  the  city's  mechanism  of  maintaining  national  security  has  not  been  perfected.
CE:  Social  unrest  a  potential  threat  to  national  security. HK  has  a  constitutional  obligation  to  safeguard  national  security  as  an  inalienable  part  of  China,  Carrie  Lam  says.

Lee:  Public  has  role  to  play  in  safeguarding  national  security. Secretary  for  Security  John  Lee  Ka-chiu  said  the  SAR  and  its  people  have  the  responsibility  and  obligation  to  safeguard  national  security.

HKDSE  to  start  April  24,  govt  has  alternatives  ready  if  needed. The  education  chief  also  announced  three  alternative  options  if  the  local  outbreak  worsens,  including  further  delaying  the  tests  or  canceling  them.

Luo  Huining:  HK  can't  emerge  as  weak  national  security  link. The  director  of  the  Liaison  Office,  Luo  Huining,  said  the  city's  mechanism  for  maintaining  national  security  wasn't  perfect  yet.

Ma:  HK's  judicial  independence  guaranteed  under  Basic  Law. HK's  judicial  independence  has  not  encountered  interference  by  the  mainland  authorities,  said    chief  justice  of  the  Court  of  Final  Appeal  Geoffrey  Ma.

Visitor  arrivals  to  Hong  Kong  decline  99%  in  March. The  figure  for  visitor  arrivals  to  HK  in  March  was  82,000,  a  drop  of  nearly  99%    from  the  same  time  last  year,  the  Hong  Kong  Tourism  Board  said  Wednesday.

Deputy  liaison  chief  Yang  Jian  removed  from  post. Yang  Jian  was  removed  from  the  post  of  deputy  director  of  the  Liaison  Office  of  the  Central  People's  Government  in  the  HKSAR,  according  to  the  State  Council.

HK  retailers  need  wide-ranging  contingency  plans  to  survive:  KPMG. Retailers  are  encouraged  to  consider  five  aspects  in  their  crisis  management  and  business  continuity  planning  including  cash  reserves,  employee  safety  etc.

Sa  Sa  reports  big  drop  in  sales  for  first  three  months  of  2020. The  Hong  Kong  cosmetic  store  chain  said  this  was  due  to  a  sharp  decline  in  the  number  of  Chinese  mainland  tourists  visiting  its  stores.

COVID-19  prevention  viewed  as  vital  to  national  security. Zhong  Nanshan  and  other  medical  experts  shared  their  insights  on  national  security  in  videos  dedicated  to  the  National  Security  Education  Day.

HK  sees  single-digit  rise  in  COVID-19  infection  for  4th  day. HK  recorded  four  new  COVID-19  cases  on  Wednesday  —  marking  the  fourth  straight  day  of  single-digit  increase  in  the  city  —  taking  the  tally  to  1,016.

HK  marks  5th  National  Security  Education  Day. The  Hong  Kong  Policy  Research  Institute  has  set  up  a  website  on  National  Security  Day  2020  to  promote  &  enhance  public  awareness  of  national  security​  in  HK.

CE:  Social  unrest,  if  unchecked,  threatens  national  security. Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  made  the  remarks  in  a  video  address  as  the  city  marked  the  fifth  National  Security  Education  Day.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.19%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  290.06  points,  or  1.19  percent,  to  24,145.34  points.

Enacting  national  security  law  urged. Hong  Kong’s  political  leaders  urged  the  special  administrative  region  government  on  Tuesday  to  put  national  security  law  legislation  on  the  agenda,  in  order  to  end  such  conduct  for  the  sake  of  Hong  Kong’s  future  prospects.

CE  rejects  claims  of  central  government  interference. Actual  meddling  is  what  some  lawmakers  sought  to  achieve  by  lobbying  foreign  govts  to  impose  sanctions  on  HK,  Carrie  Lam  says.

Kwok  abused  power,  failed  to  do  his  duties,  political  leaders  say. Opposition  lawmaker  Dennis  Kwok's  efforts  to  stymie  the  election  of  House  Committee  chairman  amounts  to  misconduct,  political  figures  in  HK  said.

CE  refutes  claims  of  central  govt's  interference  in  HKSAR  affairs. Carrie  Lam  has  refuted  the  accusation  that  the  comments  by  the  central  government  and  its  liaison  office  in  HK  on  the  malfunctioning  of  the  LegCo  constitute  interference.
LegCo  head:  Performance  of  House  Committee  unsatisfactory. The  House  Committee  has  yet  to  elect  its  chairman  and  deputy  chairman  after  14  meetings  over  the  past  six  months.

Man  receives  10-month  prison  sentence  for  possession  of  offensive  weapon. A  man  received  a  10-month  prison  sentence  after  admitting  guilt  to  three  offenses,  including  possessing  offensive  weapons  amid  the  social  unrest  last  year.

HK  urged  to  enact  national  security  law. Political  heavyweights  have  urged  the  govt  to  plug  legal  loopholes  &  minimize  the  threats  to  public  safety  illustrated  in  the  protracted  civil  unrest  last  year.

HK  reports  3  new  infections,  lowest  daily  count  in  a  month. Hong  Kong  reported  3  new  coronavirus  cases  –  the  lowest  daily  increase  since  March  12  –  bringing  the  city's  infection  tally  to  1,012.

LegCo  impasse:  'Appropriate'  for  central  authorities  to  speak  out. Legislator  Regina  Ip  Lau  Suk-yee  said  that  a  legislature  that  fails  to  function  is  detrimental  to  the  well-being  of  all  Hong  Kong  residents.

Hong  Kong  police  make  biggest  seizure  of  cannabis. The  haul,  totaling  580  kg,  were  seized  during  a  raid  at  Kwai  Chung  in  the  early  hours  of  Monday  morning  and  three  men  were  arrested,  police  said.

LegCo  quagmire  condemned  by  HK  political  leaders. Political  heavyweights  have  condemned  opposition  lawmakers  of  failing  to  perform  their  duties  in  public  office  by  paralyzing  the  legislature  for  6  months.

Opposition  condemned  for  HK  LegCo  quagmire. The  central  govt  bodies  that  oversee  matters  affecting  Hong  Kong  strongly  condemned  opposition  lawmakers  who  obstruct  LegCo's  operation.

HKMAO  backs  HK  court  ruling  that  anti-mask  law  constitutional. A  HKMAO  spokesman  said  the  ruling  will  help  the  law-based  governance  of  the  CE  and  the  HKSAR  govt,  especially  in  effectively  maintaining  public  order.

Travelers  from  US,  Europe  to  be  tested  upon  arrival  in  HK. The  HK  govt  aims  to  expand  the  arrangement  in  the  near  future  to  cover  all  foreign  arrivals,  HK's  secretary  for  food  and  health  said  Sunday.

HK  sees  2nd  day  of  single-digit  increase  in  COVID-19  infections. Of  the  latest  cases,  five  patients  are  Hong  Kong  residents  returning  variously  from  South  America,  Indonesia,  and  the  United  Kingdom.

Education  secretary:  DSE  highly  likely  to  start  on  April  24. The  date  for  DSE,  originally  scheduled  for  March  27,  was  later  postponed  to  April  24  when  the  COVID-19  outbreak  intensified.

HK  LegCo  urged  to  pass  relief  package  without  delay. The  relief  package  must  pass  in  a  timely  manner  to  help  the  SAR's  financially  battered  businesspeople  and  employees,  Chief  Secretary  Matthew  Cheung  said.

HK  top  officials  take  20%  less  income  amid  pandemic. Senior  government  officials  face  a  20%  reduction  in  their  annual  salaries,  through  a  combination  of  voluntary  income  cuts  and  previously  announced  donations.

Coronavirus  cases  in  HK  drop  to  4,  signaling  a  downtrend. Of  the  latest  cases,  three  were  Hong  Kong  residents  returning  from  the  United  States,  the  United  Kingdom,  and  Canada.

LegCo  urged  to  approve  HK$137.5b  relief  package  without  delay. Chief  Secretary  Matthew  Cheung  made  the  plea  to  legislators  to  consider  the  “urgent  needs  of  the  people”  in  deliberating  the  relief  package.

HK  residents  urged  to  stay  alert  as  infection  tally  hits  1,000. Microbiologist  Yuen  Kwok-yung  predicted  that  it  is  unlikely  to  fully  contain  the  epidemic  by  July,  even  with  current  precautionary  measures  in  place.
HK  sees  11  new  COVID-19  infections  as  tally  hits  1,000. Hong  Kong’s  tally  of  the  novel  coronavirus  cases  reached  1,000  on  Saturday,  as  authorities  announced  11  new  cases.

26  residents  stranded  in  Morocco  return  to  Hong  Kong. In  a  Facebook  post  issued  on  Friday,  Carrie  Lam  said  the  care  from  the  nation  is  the  very  guarantee  for  HK  residents  under  the  "one  country,  two  systems."
HK's  edge  over  Singapore  shows  early  social  distancing  works. Singapore  may  be  paying  the  price  for  a  strategy  that  sought  to  minimize  disruption.

Councilors  condemned  for  displaying  anti-China  banners. Two  opposition  district  councilors  were  roundly  condemned  for  putting  up  banners  in  their  constituencies  insulting  the  nation.

Stranded  in  Morocco:  27  HK  residents  arrive  in  Guangzhou. 27  HK  residents  who  had  been  stranded  in  Morocco  arrived  in  Guangzhou  Friday  on  a  chartered  flight  arranged  by  the  Chinese  Embassy  in  Morocco.

HK:  1  local  infection  among  16  new  cases,  tally  at  989. A  28-year-old  man  tested  positive  for  the  disease  on  Friday  was  believed  to  be  linked  to  the  city’s  largest  infection  cluster  involving  several  bars.

Court  of  Appeal  rules  anti-mask  legislation  constitutional. The  judgment  came  after  the  SAR  govt  appealed  a  High  Court  judgment  that  ruled  the  Emergency  Regulations  Ordinance  violated  the  Basic  Law.

64  bar  customers  face  fine  for  violating  ban  on  gatherings. The  64  who  patronized  a  bar  are  believed  to  be  the  largest  group  of  people  to  be  fined  since  a  public  gathering  ban  was  enacted  on  March  29.
HK$137b  relief  package  for  businesses  hailed. The  relief  measures  have  been  welcomed  as  a  strong  package  to  safeguard  jobs  and  support  a  wider  range  of  battered  industries.

HK  sees  13  new  infections,  slowest  daily  rise  in  3  weeks. Hong  Kong  reported  on  Thursday  13  new  coronavirus  cases  –  the  smallest  daily  increase  since  March  17  –  taking  its  infection  tally  to  973.

HK  tourism  chief  pins  hopes  on  recovery  starting  by  July. The  head  of  the  tourism  board  said  it  would  focus  on  boosting  local  consumer  spending  and  promoting  the  city  to  new  markets  such  as  India  and  Vietnam.

HK  appeals  court  rules  anti-mask  law  partially  constitutional. The  Court  of  Appeal  has  ruled  constitutional  a  government  ban  on  wearing  face  masks  at  unauthorized  assemblies  but  not  at  authorized  ones.

Airport  Authority  executives  take  20%  pay  cut. The  chief  executive  officer  and  six  executive  directors  of  the  Airport  Authority  Hong  Kong  will  take  a  20  percent  pay  cut  for  six  months.

Li  Ka-shing's  son  among  tycoons  seeking  cheap  assets  after  rout. Asian  tycoons  are  looking  to  snap  up  assets  pummeled  by  the  epidemic,  but  they  also  face  hurdles  as  govts  seek  to  deter  foreign  takeovers  of  local  firms.

HK  pushes  US$17.7b  stimulus  to  avoid  'massive  layoffs'. HK  is  likely  still  months  away  from  considering  an  exit  plan  from  the  current  crisis,  said  Executive  Council  convener  Bernard  Chan.
Hong  Kong  stocks  rise  on  hopes  of  pandemic  peak. The  Hang  Seng  Index  gained  1.38%  to  close  Thursday's  session  at  24,300.33.

27  HK  residents  stranded  in  Morocco  to  leave  for  Guangzhou. The  27  people  and  some  other  Chinese  nationals  stranded  in  Morocco  will  leave  on  Thursday  night  via  a  flight  chartered  by  the  Chinese  Embassy  in  Morocco.

TCM  helps  seniors  prosper  in  health  battle. Practitioners  of  traditional  Chinese  medicine  believe  their  ancient  skill  can  play  a  major  role  in  defeating  the  coronavirus  pandemic.

HK  has  outperformed  many  in  virus  control. The  govt's  painstaking  efforts  to  strike  a  balance  in  the  difficult  situation,  however,  make  it  an  easy  target  for  criticism,  said  Tommy  Cheung  Yu-yan.

World  needs  ‘aggressive’  measures  to  fight  COVID-19. Former  WHO  chief  speaks  highly  of
China’s  experience  in  virus  response.
HK  unveils  up  to  HK$137.5  billion  in  new  relief  package. Hong  Kong  Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  said  that  HK$80  billion  will  be  allocated  to  saving  jobs.
Executive  councilor  slams  unlawful  public  gathering. Tommy  Cheung  Yu-yan  rebukes  irresponsible  breaches  of  social-distancing  measures.
Co-living  —  bridging  the  housing  gap  in  the  city. Sharing  apartment  with  other  millennials  offers  short-term  way  to  afford  home.

Respecting  ecosystems  key  to  thwarting  new  diseases. Pandemic  another  warning  from  nature,  adding  to  more  than  70  percent  of  new  diseases  in  the  past  four  decades  that  have  come  from  animals,  says  Margaret  Chan  Fung  Fu-chun.
HK  govt  to  pay  for  truck  drivers’  virus  tests. The  mainland  authorities  will  conduct  on-site  tests  for  truck  drivers  from  Hong  Kong.  Each  test  costs  HK$350.

Hong  Kong's  cloud  economy  grows  amid  COVID-19  epidemic. The  demand  of  online  food  ordering  and  delivering  surged  and  some  restaurants  beefed  up  their  take-out  services  to  keep  business  afloat.

Hong  Kong's  airport  eyes  US$2.6b  loan  for  third  runway. Hong  Kong's  Airport  Authority  is  in  talks  with  banks  for  a  HK$20b  loan  to  help  fund  the  city's  third  runway,  according  to  people  familiar  with  the  matter.

LegCo  election  tentatively  scheduled  for  Sept  6. The  SAR  govt  is  scheduled  to  hold  the  2020  LegCo  General  Election  on  Sept  6,  but  the  plan  might  be  adjusted  in  light  of  the  coronavirus  situation.

HK  pageant  suspended  for  first  time  in  47  years  over  pandemic. HK's  annual  beauty  contest  –  Miss  Hong  Kong  Pageant  –  has  been  suspended  for  the  first  time  since  1973  due  to  the  virus  outbreak,  according  to  media  reports.

HK  unveils  HK$137.5b  in  relief  to  help  cushion  virus  impact. The  package  will  include  a  HK$80  billion  job  security  program  to  subsidize  50%  of  wages  for  affected  workers  for  6  months,  said  Carrie  Lam  at  a  press  briefing.

HK  extends  curbs  to  April  23;  beauty,  massage  places  on  list. HK  has  also  started  testing  travelers  arriving  at  its  airport  in  a  bid  to  stamp  out  a  rebound  in  COVID-19  cases  brought  on  by  imported  infections.

HK  sees  25  new  cases;  3  linked  to  Marks  &  Spencer  cluster. 15  out  of  the  25  newly  confirmed  virus  infections  on  Wednesday  had  recent  overseas  travel  history  as  the  city's  tally  now  stands  at  960.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.17%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  282.92  points,  or  1.17  percent,  to  23,970.37  points.

HK  expats  ship  masks  home  to  virus  hot  spots  as  supplies  return. An  expatriate  living  in  Hong  Kong  said  she  bought  200  masks  to  send  to  Spain  and  France,  where  prices  were  up  to  15  times  higher.

Commissioner's  office  slams  US  politicians'  unwarranted  remarks. The  commissioner's  office  in  HK  issued  a  statement  in  reply  to  unwarranted  remarks  made  by  some  US  politicians  targeting  HK  &  mainland  as  a  whole.

CE:  RTHK  must  uphold  ‘one  country,  two  systems’  principle. Lam  made  the  remarks  in  response  to  a  question  raised  by  an  RTHK  scribe  about  the  possibility  of  Taiwan's  membership  in  an  interview  with  a  WHO  official.

Stricter  enforcement  urged  on  social  gathering  breaches. The  appeal  was  made  after  a  lawmaker  flouted  a  ban  on  assemblies  of  more  than  4  people  by  attending  a  gathering  at  a  bar  attended  by  about  40  people.

Expert:  Govt  should  urge  large  private  clinics  to  test  for  virus. A  veteran  doctor  made  the  comments  after  HK's  health  authorities  appealed  to  private  clinics  to  have  more  of  their  patients  go  in  for  COVID-19  tests.

Outlook  for  HK's  prime  office  market  is  grim  due  to  coronavirus. Office  rents  in  HK  plunged  4.1  percent  quarter-on-quarter  to  HK$70  per  square  foot  on  average  in  the  first  three  months  of  2020,  Cushman  &  Wakefield  said.

More  HK  executives  keen  to  explore  Bay  Area. Shenzhen,  in  particular,  is  a  magnet  for  these  talents,  according  to  accounting  firm  KPMG’s  latest  annual  Hong  Kong  Executive  Salary  Outlook  survey.
MTR  to  begin  Tung  Chung  line  extension  work  in  2023. The  rail  operator  said  the  project  comprises  2  new  stations  and  the  Airport  Railway  extended  overrun  tunnel.

HK  sees  21  new  infections,  7  linked  to  karaoke,  bar  clusters. Three  newly  confirmed  patients  were  colleagues  of  a  48-year-old  salesman  of  Marks  &  Spencer  in  Hong  Kong  who  was  confirmed  to  be  infected  on  Monday.

HSBC  investment  units  fined  US$450k  for  regulatory  breaches. HK's  markets  regulator  fined  two  HSBC  units  HK$3.5  million  on  Tuesday  for  regulatory  breaches  when  placing  money  in  HSBC  bank  accounts.

Tycoon  Li  acquires  larger  stakes  in  his  flagship  companies. This  further  underscores  his  confidence  in  the  business  prospects  of  the  port-to-telecom  conglomerate  and  the  property  company.

Lam:  Job  protection  focus  of  2nd  round  of  virus  relief  measures. The  CE  said  that  business  and  labor  representatives  she  had  met  so  far  had  shown  the  greatest  concern  about  the  job  security  of  workers.

CE:  RTHK  must  uphold  the  'one  country,  two  systems'  principle. Lam  made  the  remarks  in  response  to  a  question  raised  by  an  RTHK  journalist  on  the  possibility  of  Taiwan's  membership  during  an  interview  with  a  WHO  official.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  2.12%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  504.17  points,  or  2.12  percent,  to  24,253.29  points.

Bankers  scramble  to  catch  wave  of  Hong  Kong  take-private  deals. Announced  take-private  and  buyout  offers  for  Hong  Kong  companies  surged  to  US$7.3  billion  this  year,  data  compiled  by  Bloomberg  shows.

Hong  Kong  consumer  lender  PrimeCredit  explores  sale. PrimeCredit  is  working  with  HSBC  for  a  potential  sale  aimed  for  a  valuation  of  US$500m  to  US$1b,  according  to  people  familiar  with  the  matter.
Tougher  action  urged  in  HK  against  coronavirus. Ho  Pak-leung  urged  the  government  to  introduce  emergency  laws  to  make  mask-wearing  compulsory  in  all  public  places.

CE  says  opposition  lawmaker’s  pub  gathering  flouted  ban. Carrie  Lam  said  that  the  gathering  of  40  people  did  not  qualify  for  an  exemption  from  the  ban  on  public  gatherings  involving  more  than  four  people.

Valentino  shock  for  fashion  shoppers. Valentino  closed  down  its  flagship  store  in  Tsim  Sha  Tsui,  in  a  further  sign  COVID-19  and  the  social  unrest  have  taken  toll  on  HK's  luxury  retail  industry.

CE  says  opp  lawmaker’s  pub  gathering  flouted  ban. About  40  people,  including  lawmaker  Tanya  Chan  Suk-chong,  were  reported  to  have  gathered  at  a  bar  amid  a  ban  on  public  gatherings  of  more  than  4  people.

24  new  cases  push  HK  virus  tally  to  more  than  900. Among  the  latest  patients  identified  on  Monday,  18  reported  recent  travel  history,  including  five  people  returning  from  Peru  on  Sunday.

HSBC  HK  shareholders  mull  suit  over  dividend  suspension. HSBC  and  other  top  British  banks  announced  the  suspension  of  dividend  payouts  after  pressure  from  the  regulator  to  conserve  capital.

Entry  restriction  on  non-HK  residents  extended  indefinitely. The  HKSAR  government  announced  on  Monday  that  it  will  extend  the  entry  restriction  on  non-Hong  Kong  residents  coming  from  overseas.

HK  financial  system  remains  resilient,  finance  chief  says. Stress  tests  indicate  even  in  extremely  adverse  situations,  banks,  intermediaries  in  securities  sector  and  insurers  can  still    meet  regulatory  requirements,  Lau  said.

Ousted  lawmaker  guilty  of  assaulting  police  with  bullhorn. An  ousted  opposition  camp  lawmaker  was  convicted  on  Monday  of  assaulting  two  police  officers  with  a  bullhorn  during  a  protest  in  July.

HK  faces  delays  in  giving  cash  away  with  virus  hitting  economy. The  Hong  Kong  government  says  the  cash  handout  needs  technical  and  legal  work,  and  that  is  moving  more  slowly  than  the  epidemic.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  2.21%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  513.01  points,  or  2.21  percent,  to  23,749.12  points.

HK  sees  fewer  new  cases  of  COVID-­19. Policymakers  &  experts  warned  that  the  declining  number  of  newly  confirmed  cases  should  not  be  taken  to  mean  that  the  pandemic  trend  has  changed.

HK  govt  mulling  more  relief  measures  to  cushion  virus  impact. Some  Hong  Kong  firms  are  facing  a  cash  flow  squeeze  due  to  rise  in  cancelled  orders  from  overseas  customers,  said  Financial  Secretary  Paul  Chan.
HK  sees  28  new  cases;  122  police  officers  to  be  quarantined. Hong  Kong  on  Sunday  confirmed  28  new  coronavirus  infection  cases,  bringing  the  total  to  890.

Coronavirus:  65  HK  residents  stranded  in  Peru  return  home. Immigration  Department  had  received  requests  for  assistance  from  98  Hong  Kong  residents.  Of  them,  13  left  Peru  by  other  means.

​
US$7.87m  needed  to  repair  vandalized  govt  properties. Radical  protesters  vandalized  about  40  government  properties  during  protracted  social  unrest  that  began  in  June  last  year.

Hong  Kong  urged  to  step  up  efforts  in  Basic  Law  education. Legal  experts,  political  leaders  and  educators  have  called  for  greater  efforts  in  educating  the  public  and  promoting  the  Basic  Law.

Luo:  HK  bears  constitutional  obligation  for  national  security. Luo  Huining,  director  of  the  liaison  office  in  Hong  Kong,  shared  his  views  in  an  article  on  the  30th  anniversary  of  the  promulgation  of  the  Basic  Law.

Liaison  chief:  HK  must  uphold  Basic  Law  despite  challenges. Luo  Huining  has  called  on  Hong  Kong  compatriots  to  stay  committed  to  the  principle  of  "one  country,  two  systems"  in  spite  of  difficulties.

HK  to  mark  30th  anniversary  of  Basic  Law  promulgation. The  HKSAR  govt  said  it  will  organize  a  series  of  activities  to  promote  the  Constitution  and  the  Basic  Law  to  various  sectors  of  the  community.

Hospital  patient  among  17  new  coronavirus  cases  in  HK. The  city’s  856th  case  involved  a  93-year-old  man  who  was  admitted  to  Pok  Oi  Hospital  on  March  10  for  stroke  and  was  discharged  on  April  2.

The  Basic  Law  —  best  safeguard  for  HK's  prosperity  and  stability. CE  Carrie  Lam,  writing  on  the  30th  anniversary  of  its  adoption,  said  the  Basic  Law  has  served  the  city  well,  and  will  continue  to  in  the  future.

Hong  Kong  mourns  for  lives  lost  to  COVID-19. Hong  Kong's  government  officials  and  residents  observed  a  three-minute  silence  on  Saturday  to  mourn  those  to  lost  their  lives  in  the  epidemic  fight.

Legal  experts:  Basic  Law  crucial  to  HK's  prosperity,  stability. The  Basic  Law  has  played  a  key  role  in  safeguarding  the  prosperity  and  stability  of  the  HKSAR  during  the  past  over  20  years,  renowned  legal  experts  said.

HK  residents'  responsibilities  in  implementing  Basic  Law  stressed. Tam  Yiu-chung,  a  member  of  the  Basic  Law  Drafting  Committee,  shared  his  views  ahead  of  the  30th  anniversary  of  the  promulgation  of  the  Basic  Law.

Basic  Law  hailed  as  'cornerstone'  of  HK's  stability  and  prosperity. Political  heavyweights  said  the  Basic  Law  of  the  HKSAR  has  guaranteed  the  smooth  implementation  of  "one  country,  two  systems"  since  1997.

SAR  urged  to  firmly  adhere  to  Basic  Law. An  article  on  People's  Daily  described  the  Basic  Law's  promulgation  as  a  milestone  in  turning  "one  country  two  systems"  from  concept  to  reality.

HK  people  advised  against  tomb-sweeping. Health  experts  warn  of  an  “invisible”  chain  of  local  coronavirus  infections,  as  the  city  reported  three  more  cases  of  local  transmission  with  unknown  infection  sources.
HK  sees  5  more  bar-related  infections  as  tally  hits  845. Hong  Kong  recorded  43  new  coronavirus  cases  on  Friday,  taking  the  tally  to  845.

Hong  Kong  to  join  national  mourning  for  COVID-19  victims. The  national  flag  and  the  HKSAR  regional  flag  displayed  at  the  HKSAR  government  offices  will  be  flown  at  half  staff  as  a  token  of  mourning  Saturday.

Light  show  staged  in  support  of  medical  workers. The  event's  organizer  Hong  Kong  Community  Anti-Coronavirus  Link  has  also  appealed  to  people  to  stay  at  home  and  avoid  social  gatherings.

HK  business  activity  slumps  further  in  March  amid  outbreak. While  HK's  PMI  edged  up  to  34.9  in  March,  from  33.1  in  Feb,  it  still  signaled  the  2nd-sharpest  deterioration  of  private  sector  conditions  since  July  1998.

Cathay  cuts  skeleton  capacity  even  more  as  demand  vanishes. The  airline  and  its  Cathay  Dragon  unit  are  reducing  capacity  by  97  percent  across  their  passenger  networks  this  month.
Hong  Kong  shares  down  0.19%. The  Hang  Seng  Index  fell  43.95  points  to  close  at  23,236.11  points  on  Friday.

Leung:  Tighter  measures  may  be  needed  to  contain  the  virus. Leung  Chi-chiu,  a  doctor  specializing  in  respiratory  science,  warned  that  the  coronavirus  situation  in  Hong  Kong  has  now  reached  a  'tipping  point'  .
Two  more  beauticians  infected  as  bars  to  close. Hong  Kong  has  now  recorded  four  COVID-19  cases  of  the  coronavirus  relating  to  beauty  parlors.

RTHK  urged  to  be  professional  after  controversial  show. In  an  episode  of  the  RTHK  show  The  Pulse,  an  anchorwoman  interviewed  a  WHO  expert  and  asked  if  the  WHO  would  reconsider  Taiwan  membership.

Doctor:  ‘Convalescing  power’  should  be  maximized. Leung  Chi-chiu  argues  that  it  might  be  effective  to  relocate  young  patients  with  minor  symptoms  to  quarantine  centers  or  their  home.

FM's  commissioner  in  HK  urges  British  politicians  to  stop  distorting  the  truth. Commissioner's  Office  expresses  'firm  opposition'  to  remarks  by  Benedict  Rogers,  HK  Watch  founder,  and  a  British  politician  about  China's  countermeasures  against  US  restrictions  on  Chinese  media  agencies.

Two  more  beauticians  among  37  new  COVID-19  cases  in  HK. Two  more  beauticians  are  among  another  37  people  in  Hong  Kong  found  to  be  infected  with  COVID-19  on  Thursday,  bringing  the  city's  tally  to  802.

HK  bars,  pubs  to  shut  for  14  days  as  city  sees  37  new  infections. HK  further  tightens  social  distancing  as  the  city  reported  37  new  cases  on  Thursday,  including  a  bar  worker  who  visited  several  bars  during  the  incubation  period.

Judiciary  mulls  longer  hours,  more  hands  to  try  protest  cases. The  judiciary  is  considering  extending  service  hours  and  hiring  more  hands  for  courts  to  handle  protest-related  cases  involving  at  least  7,700  accused  persons.

Shortened  Shenzhen  Bay  Port  hours  to  reduce  people  flow. Starting  from  April  3,  the  operating  hours  of  passenger  clearance  services  will  be  adjusted  to  between  10  am  and  8  pm  until  further  notice.

HK's  GDP  projected  to  plummet  8.3%  in  Q1. Ravaged  by  the  novel  coronavirus  pandemic,  Hong  Kong's  real  gross  domestic  product  is  expected  to  plunge  by  8.3  percent  in  the  first  quarter  of  this  year.

Dootstep  specimen  pick-up  option  for  overseas  arrivals. People  returning  to  the  city  from  overseas  can  hand  in  their  specimens  for  COVID-19  tests  using  door-to-door  collection  service  from  Friday  onwards.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.84%  higher. The  Hang  Seng  Index  gained  194.27  points  to  close  at  23,280.06  points  on  Thursday.

HK  doctor  answers  call  of  duty  again. More  than  20  HK  doctors  working  at  the  University  of  Hong  Kong-Shenzhen  Hospital  have  remained  on  the  front  line  on  the  Chinese  mainland  since  Feb  10.

Tycoon  Li  adds  stakes  in  CK  Asset. HK  tycoon  Li  Ka-shing  increased  his  equity  in  CK  Asset  Holdings  as  a  signal  that  he  is  confident  in  the  business  prospects  of  the  property  flagship  firm.

HK  bans  3  more  types  of  venues  amid  pandemic. The  HK  govt  on  Wednesday  ordered  the  closures  while  reporting  51  new  cases  of  the  novel  coronavirus,  with  the  youngest  patient  an  infant  only  40  days  old.

2-week  closure  ordered  for  3  more  types  of  establishments. Karaoke  lounges  and  mahjong  parlors  joined  the  list  of  establishments  to  be  closed  for  14  days  to  contain  the  spread  of  the  novel  coronavirus.

40-day-old  baby  among  51  new  COVID-19  patients  in  HK. A  40-day-old  boy  was  confirmed  to  be  HK's  youngest  COVID-19  patient  as  the  city  saw  51  new  infections  Wednesday,  bringing  the  tally  to  765.

CE:  'One  country,  two  systems'  cornerstone  of  HK  prosperity. Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  expressed  her  views  in  an  article  published  before  the  30th  anniversary  of  the  promulgation  of  the  HKSAR  Basic  Law.

HSBC,  StanChart  slide  after  halting  dividends  at  BOE  request. ​Britain’s  biggest  banks  scrapped  their  dividends  after  regulators  pushed  them  to  free  up  more  money  for  loans  to  counter  the  fallout  from  the  epidemic.

HK  enters  5G  era  with  2  telecom  firms  rolling  out  services. China  Mobile  Hong  Kong  and  CSL  Mobile  have  begun  offering  5G  service  for  mobile  users  at  a  price  as  low  as  HK$198  per  month.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  2.19%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  517.69  points,  or  2.19  percent,  to  23,085.79  points.

3  teens  arrested  for  alleged  arson  at  police  station. The  trio  were  among  a  group  of  people  who  allegedly  threw  gasoline  bombs  at  Tai  Po  Police  Station  at  2:40  am  on  Wednesday.

HK's  gathering  ban  stokes  confusion  over  who's  exempt. Listed  firms  are  unsure  if  the  ban  applies  to  extraordinary  general  meetings  that  are  required  for  shareholders  to  approve  major  transactions.

Pet  cat  tests  positive  for  coronavirus  in  Hong  Kong. A  pet  cat  of  a  patient  diagnosed  with  COVID-19  in  Hong  Kong  has  tested  positive  for  the  virus,  the  HKSAR  government  said.

PLA  HK  garrison's  chopper  crashes,  no  resident  injured. The  helicopter  accident  occurred  during  a  flight  training  operation  conducted  in  Tai  Lam  Country  Park,  according  to  the  HKSAR  government's  Security  Bureau.

New  karaoke  cluster  among  HK  virus  spike  hotspots. Five  of  a  group  of  seven  who  went  to  karaoke  bar  Red  MR  in  Tsim  Sha  Tsui  on  March  24  have  been  confirmed  to  be  infected  with  the  coronavirus.

Campaign  assists  low-income  children. Judy  Chen,  chairman  of  UNICEF  Hong  Kong,  said  poorer  families  crammed  into  subdivided  apartments  are  believed  to  be  at  greater  risk  during  the  outbreak.

Govt-chartered  flight  to  bring  back  HK  residents  from  Peru. Plane  to  leave  on  Friday  from  Peruvian  capital  Lima  as  the  SAR  government  received  91  calls  for  assistance  from  people  stranded  in  the  South  American  country.

HK  retail  sales  see  record  44%  slump  in  February. Hong  Kong's  struggling  retail  sales  have  been  battered  by  the  months-long  citywide  violent  protests  and  the  novel  coronavirus  pandemic.
Virus  decimates  HK  retail  sales  value  by  record  44%  in  Feb. The  slide  in  retail  sales  in  February  marks  13  straight  months  of  negative  readings.

HK  sees  32  new  infections,  four  linked  to  karaoke  cluster. Four  of  the  new  patients  are  among  a  group  of  seven  who  went  to  karaoke  bar  Red  MR  on  March  24,  health  officials  said.

CE  pledges  new  round  of  subsidy  for  catering,  retail  sectors. Once  released,  this  will  be  the  second  phase  of  government  subsidy  to  help  the  catering  and  retail  industries  to  tide  over  the  current  economic  crisis.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.85%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  428.37  points,  or  1.85  percent,  to  23,603.48  points.

HKDSE  'may  be  further  postponed'. This  year's  Diploma  of  Secondary  Education  exams,  originally  scheduled  to  begin  on  March  27,  has  already  been  postponed  by  4  weeks  to  late  April.

HK-ASEAN  free  trade  pact  effective  in  May  for  Philippines. The  part  relating  to  the  Philippines  under  the  Free  Trade  Agreement  and  the  Investment  Agreement  between  HK  and  ASEAN  will  take  effect  on  May  12.
HKMA:  Uncertainties  may  dent  banks'  profits. The  Hong  Kong  Monetary  Authority  has  warned  that  local  banks  may  face  challenges  in  maintaining  their  profitability.
21-year-old  arrested  for  allegedly  wounding  HKUST  student. The  suspect,  also  an  HKUST  student,  faces  a  maximum  penalty  of  three  years  in  prison  if  convicted.
HK  records  41  new  cases  as  isolation  beds  fill  up. The  rise  in  infection  numbers  has  pushed  the  occupancy  rate  of  1,012  isolation  beds  in  public  hospitals  to  65  percent.

Three  sent  to  prison  for  breaching  quarantine  orders. Govt  said  the  deterrent  sentences  sent  a  clear  message  to  society  that  zero  tolerance  will  be  shown  to  people  who  breach  quarantine  orders.

CUHK  offers  stool  tests  to  screen  arriving  children. HK's  Department  of  Health  has  teamed  with  the  Chinese  University  of  Hong  Kong  to  beef  up  its  capacity  to  identify  patients  infected  with  the  coronavirus.

Lam  vows  zero  tolerance  for  quarantine  breaches  as  3  jailed. A  31-year-old  man  was  sentenced  to  three  months  in  jail,  while  the  other  two  offenders  were  sentenced  to  six  weeks  and  10  days  in  jail  respectively.

Monetary  authority:  No  massive  capital  outflows  from  HK. The  Hong  Kong  Monetary  Authority  said  with  the  Hong  Kong  dollar  remaining  firm,  the  aggregate  balance  was  stable  and  total  deposits  grew  modestly.
HK  median  wage  in  May-June  up  3.8%  yoy. The  median  monthly  wage  of  male  employees  was  HK$19,900  while  the  median  monthly  wage  of  female  employees  was  HK$15,300.

HK  reports  41  new  COVID-19  infections,  tally  touches  682. The  rapid  rise  in  infections  has  also  pushed  the  occupancy  rate  of  the  city's  1,012  isolation  beds  to  65%,  the  highest  since  the  outbreak  started  in  January.

Govt  working  to  bring  back  HK  residents  from  Peru,  Morocco. As  of  Sunday  noon,  Hong  Kong's  Immigration  Department  received  86  assistance  requests  from  HK  residents  stranded  in  Peru  &  150  from  Morocco.

HK  dollar's  best  run  since  2003  shows  no  signs  of  abating. Elevated  local  rates  relative  to  the  US  have  made  the  Hong  Kong  dollar  the  best  carry  trade  in  Asia,  and  propelled  it  to  a  0.51%  gain  this  month.

Govt’s  grassroots  support  voted  most  important  initiative. Support  for  grassroots  families  has  been  voted  the  most  important  policy  initiative  of  the  HKSAR  government  in  2019  in  a  recent  poll.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.32%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  309.17  points,  or  1.32  percent,  to  23,175.11  points.

Cheung:  HK  govt  to  launch  2nd  round  of  anti-epidemic  funding. Matthew  Cheung  said  Sunday  that  the  govt  "will  provide  financial  subsidy  to  protect  workers  and  those  affected  sectors"  amid  the  COVID-19  outbreak.

HK  backup  plans  urged  in  event  of  medical  shortages. The  appeal  was  made  after  the  city  recorded  59  new  novel  coronavirus  infection  cases  on  Sunday,  pushing  the  total  to  641.

Public  urged  to  stay  home  as  HK  sees  59  new  cases. Forty  of  the  new  cases  confirmed  Sunday,  including  18  students  returning  from  the  US  and  the  UK,  had  traveled  overseas  during  the  incubation  period.

HK  sees  64  new  infections,  tally  reaches  582. ​The  new  patients  involved  40  men  and  24  women  aged  between  7  and  76.  Among  them,  47  had  travel  history  and  26  are  overseas  students.

US  politicians  urged  to  stop  meddling  in  HKSAR  affairs. A  spokesperson  for  the  Commissioner’s  Office  of  the  Foreign  Ministry  in  the  HKSAR  also  called  on  Human  Rights  Watch  not  to  go  further  down  the  wrong  path.

Govt:  HK's  competitive  edges  remain  intact  despite  unrest. In  a  report  published  by  Z/Yen,  HK  was  ranked  number  six  in  the  Global  Financial  Index,  dropping  3  places  from  the  last  ranking.
Lost  in  Hong  Kong  –  Liu  Xin's  perspective. CGTN  senior  host  and  journalist  Liu  Xin  checks  out  the  demands  of  Hong  Kong  protesters  to  understand  more  about  the  situation.

Recyclers  receive  govt  subsidies  to  ride  out  crisis. A  total  amount  of  HK$5.6  million  in  subsidy  has  been  distributed  to  the  city's  recyclers  to  cover  their  rental  and  operation  costs  amid  the  epidemic.

Govt  to  gazette  ban  on  gathering  of  more  than  4  people. The  new  measure,  under  the  Prevention  and  Control  of  Diseases  (Prohibition  on  Group  Gathering)  Regulation,  will  commence  on  Sunday.
HK  doing  ‘reasonably  well’  in  virus  control,  says  former  WHO  adviser. But  professor  Keiji  Fukuda  warned  that  COVID-19  is  not  something  that  will  last  for  just  a  few  weeks.

HK  bans  gatherings  of  over  4  people  as  daily  tally  hits  record. The  measures,  introduced  under  the  Prevention  and  Control  of  Disease  Regulation,  are  among  the  toughest  in  the  city’s  fight  against  the  virus  so  far.

HK  to  limit  public  gatherings  to  4,  shut  establishments. Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  also  ordered  to  shut  party-room  rental  services  and  public  entertainment  venues  for  14  days  starting  from  6  pm  on  Saturday.

HK  sees  largest  daily  rise  in  infections  with  65  new  cases. Hong  Kong  on  Friday  recorded  its  largest-ever  single-day  jump  in  coronavirus  infections  with  65  new  cases,  bringing  the  tally  to  518.

77  home  quarantine  breaches  found. Secretary  for  Security  John  Lee  criticized  home  quarantine  violators  for  being  “very  irresponsible”  and  thanked  those  who  had  reported  the  violations.

HK  to  test  arrivals  for  coronavirus  at  all  entry  points. The  govt  is  planning  to  extend  to  all  entry  points  the  requirement  for  asymptomatic  arrivals  to  provide  samples  of  deep-throat  saliva  for  testing.

Police  seize  dangerous  weapons,  arrest  4. Police  have  seized  a  large  cache  of  homemade  ammunition  and  chemicals  believed  to  be  linked  to  a  spate  of  violent  anti-government  protests.

Guangdong  to  quarantine  all  arrivals;  HK,  Macao  not  exempt. Personnel  helping  ensure  normal  life  &  production  in  HK  &  Macao  and  those  ferrying  supplies  to  the  SARs  won't  be  quarantined.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.56%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  131.94  points,  or  0.56  percent,  to  23,484.28  points.

Quarantine  a  boon  for  some  HK  hotels  as  thousands  return. As  thousands  of  citizens  and  expatriates  return  to  the  city,  many  are  seeking  refuge  in  hotels,  fearful  that  cramped  apartments  could  put  families  at  risk.

Six  more  mask  production  lines  to  get  govt  subsidies. The  monthly  output  of  the  6  production  lines  will  be  sufficient  to  provide  an  average  of  10  million  masks  to  the  govt  and  20,000  others  to  the  local  market.
2-day  evacuation  brings  558  back  to  HK. On  the  chartered  flights,  there  were  23  people  aged  over  60,  and  140  children  under  16.
Online  sales  shine  as  pent-up  demand  fueled. Retailers  aggressively  promote  discounts  online  amid  signs  of  economic  recovery.

Hoteliers  unable  to  see  light  at  the  end  of  the  tunnel. As  inbound  tourism  continues  to  bear  the  brunt  of  COVID-19,  HK  hoteliers  remain  pessimistic  about  what  the  market  holds  in  the  first  half  of  this  year.
Govt  devising  tougher  controls  on  gatherings. City  records  43  new  cases  on  Thursday,  the  third-highest  single-day  jump.
'It's  right  on  the  street  where  I  live'. Founder  and  chief  executive  of  Ovolo  Group  said  he  learned  from  his  father  to  be  patient  and  that  good  ideas  take  time.
Hospitality  with  a  brave  face. A  Hong  Kong-based  hospitality  group  battles  to  survive  the  impact  of  months  of  social  unrest  and  the  novel  coronavirus.

Clawing  back  a  living  in    an  'ice  age'  for  retailers. The  soured  business  climate  has  led  to  change  of  business  modes  as  well  as  a  major  shift  in  the  commercial  property  market.

Govt,  social  groups  race  against  time  to  get  children’s  masks. DAB  member  Li  Sai-wing  said  once  schools  reopen,  parents  will  have  to  supply  50  to  60  pieces  per  child  every  month,  adding  to  the  burden  of  parents.

Businesses  livestream  to  keep  themselves  afloat. Using  a  cellphone,  a  tripod  and  a  microphone,  Hong  Kong  cosmetics  salespersons  have  taken  to  livestreaming  to  overcome  the  “retail  ice  age”  amid  the  coronavirus  pandemic.
Three  arrested  after  explosives  seized. Three  men  in  their  20s  were  arrested  on  Thursday  night  after  police  seized  suspected  offensive  weapons  in  a  cottage  in  Siu  Sai  Wan.

HK:  'Opposition  councilor'  arrested  for  alleged  sedition. Local  media  has  identified  a  woman  arrested  by  police  for  alleged  seditious  acts  as  Central  and  Western  District  Council  chairwoman  Cheng  Lai-king.

Another  277  HK  residents  return  from  Hubei. A  total  of  277  Hong  Kong  residents  returned  to  the  city  on  Thursday  on  two  government-chartered  flights  after  being  stranded  in  Hubei  for  over  two  months.

HK's  Feb  exports  rise  4.3%  amid  slump,  falls  12%  in  first  2  months. The  fall  in  exports  reflected  the  serious  disruptions  to  regional  trading  and  production  activities  caused  by  the  virus  outbreak,  a  govt  spokesman  said.

Relief  fund  gets  'overwhelming  response'  from  retailers. About  40,000  retailers  have  applied  for  a  one-off  subsidy  of  HK$80,000  from  the  epidemic  relief  fund  that  aims  to  tide  local  businesses  over  financial  woes.

HK  considering  more  social  distancing  measures. The  government  is  considering  more  social  distancing  efforts  as  the  virus  outbreak  shows  no  sign  of  abating  in  the  city,  said  finance  chief  Paul  Chan.

Unemployment  among  low-income  families  rises  4  fold. The  number  of  unemployed  people  from  low-income  families  surged  400  percent  to  161  from  32  in  the  past  two  months,  a  survey  showed.

Developers  bank  on  online  campaigns  to  lift  sales. Chinese  property  developers  are  banking  on  online  marketing  campaigns  to  boost  sales  and  attract  buyers  as  the  coronavirus  pandemic  continues  to  roil  the  market.

HK  reports  43  new  infections;  tally  touches  453. Undersecretary  for  Food  and  Health  Chui  Tak-yi  renewed  the  call  to  maintain  social  distancing  and  urged  the  public  not  to  drop  its  guard.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.74%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  174.85  points,  or  0.74%,  to  23,352.34  points  on  Thursday.
Ban  on  crowds  urged  as  HK  virus  cases  hit  410. Halting  alcohol  sales  at  restaurants  and  bars  would  be  ineffective  in  reducing  all  types  of  social  gatherings,  experts  say.

Executive  councilor  vouches  for  efficacy  of  tight  border  control. Executive  Councilor  Lam  Ching-choi  said  the  new  measures  that  took  effect  on  Wednesday  will  block  the  importation  of  the  coronavirus  from  foreign  countries.

HK  leader  appeals  to  residents  not  to  let  guard  down. Complacency  risks  squandering  the  hard  efforts  of  Hong  Kong  citizens  in  the  past  two  months,  and  the  consequences  could  be  dire,  Carrie  Lam  says.
Another  281  make  it  home  from  Hubei. Another  two  flights  are  scheduled  to  pick  up  the  remaining  280  Hong  Kong  residents  in  the  three  cities  today.

Lam  condemns  ‘utterly  irresponsible’  quarantine  breaches. He  is  also  disappointed  that  some  Hong  Kong  people  traveled  abroad  when  the  coronavirus  was  already  seriously  affecting  overseas  countries.

LegCo  passes  HK$215.8-billion  provisional  funding  for  govt. Part  of  the  provisional  funding,  passed  with  a  vote  of  39  to  24,  will  pay  for  the  anti-coronavirus  epidemic  expenses  by  various  government  departments.

HK  booze  ban  may  wipe  out  thousands  of  bars  and  restaurants. The  govt  has  planned  to  temporarily  ban    restaurants  &  bars  from  selling  alcohol  after  several  COVID-19  patients  reportedly  had  been  out  drinking.

Chartered  flights  bring  281  HK  residents  home  from  Hubei. Another  two  flights  will  depart  for  Wuhan,  capital  of  Hubei  province,  Thursday  to  bring  back  more  Hong  Kong  residents.

Phone-snatching  lawmaker's  appeal  dismissed. Hong  Kong’s  privacy  protection  agency  said  it  is  proper  for  the  government  to  keep  track  of  the  whereabouts  of  legislators  in  the  Council’s  premises.

Hong  Kong  dollar  is  as  strong  as  it  can  get  thanks  to  Fed  cuts. The  recent  strength  follows  the  HKMA's  decision  last  week  to  cut  its  base  rate  by  64  basis  points  to  0.86%  after  the  US  Federal  Reserve's  100  basis-point  cut.
HK  confirms  24  new  infections,  tally  rises  to  410. 19  of  the  24  new  patients  had  a  history  of  travel  to  places  such  as  Europe  and  North  America,  health  officials  said.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  3.81%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  863.70  points,  or  3.81  percent,  to  23,527.19  points.
HK  residents  told  to  shun  social  gatherings. The  appeal  came  after  the  city  recorded  30  new  cases  on  Tuesday,  taking  the  tally  to  386.

Andrew  Cheung  appointed  as  Hong  Kong's  new  chief  justice. Andrew  Cheung  Kui-nung  will  succeed  Geoffrey  Ma  Tao-li  and  become  the  third  chief  justice  of  the  Court  of  Final  Appeal  since  1997.
Hotlines  to  be  set  up  to  curb  quarantine  violations. Move  to  elicit  public  surveillance  on  compliance  amid  growing  breaches  of  quarantine  rules  by  overseas  returnees.

24  violators  of  home  quarantine  order  sent  to  centers. The  Hong  Kong  government  said  that  the  Department  of  Health  and  the  police  will  follow  up  on  the  cases  before  pressing  charges,  the  statement  read.

HK  govt  to  set  up  hotlines  for  reporting  quarantine  violators. Carrie  Lam  called  on  people  quarantined  at  home  to  fulfill  their  social  responsibilities,  adding  that  violating  the  order  is  an  irresponsible  behavior.

4  chartered  flights  to  bring  back  500  HK  residents  from  Hubei. Four  chartered  flights  to  Wuhan  have  been  arranged  on  Wednesday  and  Thursday  to  pick  up  the  Hong  Kong  residents  in  Xiaogan,  Xianning,  and  Huangshi.

HK  dollar  yields  near  highest  since  1999  versus  greenback. The  Federal  Reserve's  decision  to  slash  interest  rates  to  zero  is  having  one  unintended  result  in  HK,  where  the  currency  is  near  its  strongest  since  2017.

HK  reports  30  new  infections,  tally  reaches  386. Among  the  30  new  patients,  19  of  them  have  traveled  outside  of  the  city  during  the  incubation  period,  health  authorities  said.

Hong  Kong  expats  point  fingers  over  who's  spreading  coronavirus. Returnees  to  HK  are  at  the  center  of  controversy  as  imported  cases  of  the  virus  surged  after  the  city  had  mostly  contained  the  spread  of  COVID-19.

HK  property  developer  braces  for  difficult  times  ahead. Local  home  market  to  continue  to  feel  the  pinch  from  trade  tensions,  social  unrest  and  coronavirus  pandemic,  K.  Wah  International  says.

No  ‘V-shaped’  recovery  seen  for  tourism  business. Hong  Kong  cannot  expect  to  see  a  “V-shaped”  recovery  for  the  battered  travel  industry  once  the  novel  coronavirus  outbreak  is  over,  according  to  a  tourism  official.
HK's  first  virtual  bank  debuts  with  1%  interest  rate. ZA  Bank's  ZA  Savings  Go  product  offers  customers  an  annual  savings  deposit  rate  of  1  percent  for  up  to  HK$500,000.

CE  names  new  Chief  Justice  of  the  Court  of  Final  Appeal. Upon  appointment,  Cheung  will  succeed  Geoffrey  Ma  Tao-li  and  become  the  third  Chief  Justice  of  the  Court  of  Final  Appeal.  His  term  starts  on  Jan  11,  2021.

First  of  HK's  new  online-only  banks  starts  operating. ZA  Bank  Ltd,  a  unit  of  China's  ZhongAn  Online  P&C  Insurance  Co,  is  one  of  the  eight  companies  that  were  issued  virtual  banking  licenses  in  Hong  Kong.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  4.46%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  967.36  points,  or  4.46  percent,  to  22,663.49  points.

New  system  enlisted  to  detect  travelers  with  fever. So  far,  16  kits  have  been  put  into  use  at  Hong  Kong  International  Airport  and  six  other  locations,  including  checkpoints  and  government  buildings.
Clawing  back  a  living. Hong  Kong  residents  have  been  immersed  in  deep  soul-searching  to  ride  out  what’s  deemed  to  be  one  of  toughest  economic  times  on  record.
Sustainability  of  medical  system  questioned  as  infections  soar. This  comes  as  the  city  reported  39  new  coronavirus  infections  on  Monday.

Greater  protection  for  front-line  staff  urged. The  call  was  made  after  a  doctor  and  an  employee  of  Starbucks,  both  of  whom  recently  worked  at  HK's  airport,  were  confirmed  to  be  infected  with  the  virus.
Non-HK  residents  to  be  denied  entry  at  airport. The  ban  will  come  into  force  on  Wednesday  and  is  set  to  last  for  two  weeks.

HK  reports  39  new  coronavirus  cases;  local  tally  now  at  356. Thirty  of  the  newly  confirmed  patients,  aged  18  to  66,  had  recent  record  of  travel  to  virus-stricken  countries  during  the  incubation  period.
2020  to  be  one  of  HK's  top  10  hottest  years. Four  to  seven  tropical  typhoons  expected.
HK’s  aviation  industry  gets  much-needed  HK1b  relief. Over  400  companies  to  benefit  as  worldwide  travel  restrictions  deal  fresh  blows  to  airlines  and  airport  tenants.

HK  consumer  prices  rise  2.2%  in  February. The  year-on-year  increase  beats  the  1.4  percent  uptick  in  January;  but  govt  says  pressure  on  most  major  CPI  components  remains  moderate.

Shares  of  China  Evergrande  sink  after  profit  warnings. Shares  of  the  mainland  real  estate  giant  plunged  16.89  percent  after  the  group  warned  its  profit  will  drop  50  percent  in  2019  from  a  year  earlier.

As  Wall  Street  empties,  Asia’s  bankers  slowly  head  to  work. Back  at  work  doesn't  mean  back  to  normal  for  most  bankers,  and  an  uptick  in  cases  in  HK  and  S'pore  has  authorities  cautioning  against  complacency.

Man  denied  bail  for  providing  false  home  quarantine  address. It  was  the  first  such  court  case  since  the  mandatory  quarantine  rule  was  introduced  on  Feb  8  to  contain  the  spread  of  the  COVID-19  epidemic  in  HK.

HK  stocks  fall  most  in  nearly  26  months. ​HK  stocks  fell  by  their  most  in  nearly  26  months,  as  the  Hang  Seng  index  fell  4.9%,  posting  its  biggest  drop  since  Feb  6,  2018.

41  people  found  flouting  compulsory  quarantine  orders. HK  police  caught  5  of  the  41  who  left  their  dwelling  places  without  permission,  while  the  other  36  have  been  placed  on  the  wanted  list.

Hong  Kong  bans  all  non-resident  arrivals  for  14  days. Hong  Kong  will  start  the  ban  from  midnight  on  Wednesday  and  will  stop  all  airport  transit  services,  Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  said  on  Monday.

Hong  Kong  bourse  bangs  virtual  gong  on  IPO  in  time  of  virus. InnoCare  Pharma  Ltd,  a  Chinese  mainland  biotech  firm,  on  Monday  became  the  first  IPO  to  debut  via  a  virtual  listing  ceremony  at  HKEX.
Tutoring  centers  in  HK  struggle  for  survival  amid  pandemic. A  small  tutoring  center  in  Tsuen  Wan  district  has  seen  a  90%  drop  in  students  after  the  coronavirus  outbreak.
Public  urged  to  self-regulate  to  curb  COVID-19. Hong  Kong  residents  are  urged  to  limit  travel  and  maintain  social  distance.

WHO  member  decries  naming  viruses  by  geography. HK's  leading  coronavirus  expert  Leo  Poon  Lit-man  says  we  should  contain  the  infectious  disease  for  now  and  not  point  fingers  at  each  other.
Hong  Kong  reports  44  new  cases,  taking  tally  to  317. Twenty-nine  of  the  patients  confirmed  Sunday  had  traveled  overseas  during  the  incubation  period,  health  officials  said.

Macao  reports  2  new  cases,  mulls  curbs  on  arrivals  from  HK. The  Macao  govt  said  that  it  would  not  rule  out  imposing  quarantine  on  arrivals  from  HK  where  confirmed  cases  of  coronavirus  infection  are  on  the  rise.

HK  sees  17  new  infections,  tally  reaches  273. Two  members  of  a  karate  team  that  returned  to  Hong  Kong  after  training  in  Europe  were  among  the  infected,  health  authorities  said.

HK  postpones  HKDSE  exams,  suspends  classes  indefinitely. The  govt  on  Saturday  announced  to  postpone  the  HKDSE  exam  and  extending  virus  tests  to  asymptomatic  arrivals  at  airport  in  a  bid  to  reduce  the  risk  of  community  outbreak.

HK  health  chief  says  city  in  'state  of  war'  against  coronavirus. Sophia  Chan  said  the  authorities  were  concerned  that  the  virus  outbreak  could  spin  out  of  control  despite  positive  steps  in  containment  having  been  taken.
China  Daily  scoops  9  HK  News  Awards. The  paper  has  won  awards  in  this  competition  for  10  consecutive  years,  scooping  a  total  of  84  wins  since  2010.
HK  virus  cases  shoot  up  25%  on  Friday. The  record  single-day  jump  of  48  new  cases  has  brought  the  local  tally  to  256.

RTHK  warned  after  controversial  show  drew  flak. Board  of  Advisors  Chairman  Eugene  Chan  Kin-keung  has  asked  RTHK  shows  to  abide  by  the  public  broadcaster's  charter,  which  requires  accurate  and  impartial  news  and  information.

Govt  mails  meds  to  nearly  3,000  stranded  on  the  mainland. More  than  2,600  Hong  Kong  residents  in  Guangong  and  Fujian  provinces,  as  well  as  some  200  in  Hubei  province,  have  received  medications  for  illnesses.
Drill  preps  police  for  countering  terrorism. More  than  250  officers  are  trained  to  tackle  bomb  attacks  as  terrorism-like  acts  surge  in  recent  days.

HK  Express  to  suspend  all  flight  operations  March  23-April  30. Cathay  Pacific,  meanwhile,  slashed  passenger  capacity  by  96  percent  in  April  and  May  as  the  coronavirus  shuts  down  travel  across  the  world.

HK  reports  48  new  infections,  biggest  increase  in  single  day. The  new  cases  have  brought  Hong  Kong's  total  number  of  COVID-19  cases  to  256,  according  to  the  Hong  Kong's  Centre  of  Health  Protection.

Delivery  robot  serves  in  hotel  amid  coronavirus  outbreak. A  hotel  in  Hong  Kong  has  gone  robotic  in  observing  the  social  contact  distancing  guideline  amid  the  virus  epidemic  outbreak.

ITTF  suspends  China  Open,  Hong  Kong  Open  over  virus. The  Platinum  China  Open  in  Shenzhen  and  the  Hong  Kong  Open  in  the  HKSAR  were  originally  scheduled  on  May  12-17  and  May  5-10,  respectively.

Chinese  philanthropists  promote  impact  investing  in  wake  of  pandemic. The  coronavirus  outbreak  is  a  warning  from  nature,  says  leader  of  a  charity  whose  Shenzhen  branch  just  had  a  social  impact-conscious  investment  division.
Hong  Kong  stocks  rebound,  close  5.05%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  rebounded  and  closed  up  5.05  percent  to  22,805.07  points.

Anti-terrorism  drill  against  simulated  bomb  attacks  held. The  exercise  comes  amid  rising  concerns  about  homegrown  terrorism  after  the  recent  seizures  of  homemade  bombs  &  explosives  commonly  used  by  terrorists.

First  2  local  face  mask  production  lines  to  get  subsidies. Based  on  their  committed  production  output,  the  two  production  lines  stand  to  receive  subsidies  of  up  to  HK$2.5  million  and  HK$2  million,  respectively.
Another  pet  dog  infected. The  infected  German  Shepherd's  owner  lives  in  Pok  Fu  Lam  and  it  had  been  quarantined  after  its  owner  was  confirmed  to  be  infected  with  COVID-19.

How  one  street  shows  HK's  deep-seated  economic  pain. A  walk  down  Hollywood  Road  shows  the  devastation  wrought  by  the  novel  coronavirus  and  last  year's  social  unrest  stemmed  from  the  extradition  bill.
Lam:  Govt  will  ensure  all  arrivals  quarantined  without  fail. Carrie  Lam  made  the  remarks  during  her  inspection  visit  to  Hong  Kong  International  Airport  on  Thursday  afternoon.

​Riding  out  the  storm  —  still  a  long  way  for  traders. It  seems  Hong  Kong's  trade  sector  still  has  a  long  way  to  go  to  put  itself  back  on  track  this  year,  with  considerable  uncertainties  remaining  on  the  horizon.
Hotel  quarantine  an  option  for  locals. For  many  local  residents,  home  quarantine  is  the  first  option.  But  it  is  obviously  not  always  a  safe  one.
Probe  into  virus  transmission  in  Lan  Kwai  Fong. HK  expert  suggests  youngsters  avoid  gatherings  as  imported  cases  surge.
HKUST  student  union  called  out  for  'Chinese  pneumonia'  remarks. Backlash  from  alumni  and  fellow  students  who  say  the  union  does  not  speak  for  the  university.

HK  sees  another  16  infected,  tally  touches  208. A  total  of  88  cases  were  recorded  between  March  5  and  18,  with  92  percent  of  them  being  imported  cases,  according  to  health  officials.

Leading  HK  microbiologist  withdraws  controversial  article. Yuen  Kwok-yung  &  co-author  David  Lung  said  the  inappropriate  references  and  wordings  in  the  article  published  on  Ming  Pao  weren't  their  original  intention.

History  is  on  the  side  of  HK  stocks  priced  near  all-time  low. The  Hang  Seng  Index's  2.6%  loss  on  Thursday  means  traders  are  pricing  firms’  assets  at  94%  of  their  stated  worth,  just  above  a  record  low.

New  building  enlisted  as  quarantine  center. The  unused  new  building  in  Fo  Tan  will  provide  about  400  units  for  quarantine  purpose,  said  Under-Secretary  for  Food  and  Health  Chui  Tak-yi.

CK  Hutchison  profit  up  2%,  outlook  uncertain. Share  prices  of  4  associated  companies  of  the  business  empire  of  Li  Ka-shing  tumbled  Thursday,  after  all  companies  reported  uncertain  earnings  prospects.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  2.61%  down. The  benchmark  Hang  Seng  Index  closed  Thursday's  session  at  21,709.13,  down  582.69  or  2.61  percent.

Prudential  signs  US$753m  Thai  deal  with  tycoon  Li's  FWD. Prudential's  Thai  unit  will  buy  the  exclusive  rights  from  FWD  to  sell  life  insurance  products  via  TMB  Bank,  the  Thai  lender  said  in  an  exchange  filing.
All  at  sea  with  the  coronavirus. It  has  been  a  month  since  the  first  batch  of  stranded  HK  passengers  got  off  the  virus-stricken  Diamond  Princess  and  came  back  home.

FM  calls    accusations  of  meddling  ‘absurd’. The  statement  came  after  the  Foreign  Correspondents'  Club  commented  on  Beijing's  latest  countermeasures  against  US'  restrictions  on  Chinese  media.

HK  may  expand  screening  facilities  beyond  airport. The  govt  may  enlist  AsiaWorld  Expo  &  North  Lantau  Hospital  for  testing  arrivals  as  HK  braces  for  tens  of  thousands  of  inbound  travelers  in  the  coming  weeks.

HK  sees  highest  single-day  spike  in  cases. Hong  Kong  recorded  25  new  infections  on  Wednesday,  bringing  the  city's  tally  to  192.  Twenty-two  of  the  patients  returned  from  overseas  recently.

HK  still  most  expensive  city  to  live  in. Hong  Kong  has  again  topped  the  global  list  of  the  most  expensive  cities  to  live  in,  ahead  of  Singapore  and  Osaka,  according  to  the  latest  survey  by  the  Economist  Intelligence  Unit.

Commissioner's  Office:  China's  countermeasures  legitimate. Commissioner's  Office  of  the  Chinese  Foreign  Ministry  in  the  HKSAR  has  opposed  to  unwarranted  remarks  by  HK's  Foreign  Correspondents'  Club.

Govt:  HK  enjoys  press  freedom,  open  employment  policy. A  HKSAR  government  spokesman  has  responded  to  media  enquiries  on  a  statement  by  the  Foreign  Ministry  about  countermeasures  on  the  US.

Chinese  vaccine  approved  for  human  testing  in  Wuhan. HKSAR-listed  CanSino  Biologics  said  the  vaccine  it  co-developed  with  the  Academy  of  Military  Medical  Sciences  will  undergo  clinical  trials  in  Wuhan.

146  HK  people  stranded  in  Morocco  seek  help. The  HK  travelers  were  stranded  after  Morocco  on  Sunday  suspended  all  international  passenger  flights  to  contain  the  novel  coronavirus  outbreak.

HKEx  chief  committed  to  keeping  markets  operational. Chief  Executive  of  Hong  Kong  Exchanges  and  Clearing  Limited  (HKEX)  Charles  Li  made  the  remarks  in  response  to  media  inquiry.

HK  records  14  new  infections,  most  in  a  single  day. In  the  past  24  hours,  a  total  of  60  arrivals,  32  of  whom  had  developed  symptoms,  were  sent  directly  from  the  ports  of  entry  to  hospitals  for  treatment.

Govt  to  conduct  coronavirus  tests  for  high-risk  arrivals. An  ExCo  member  said  people  with  light  symptoms,  from  a  pandemic  stricken  region  or  who  live  in  a  cramped  flat  with  family  members  will  be  tested.

Face  masks  still  in  short  supply  as  global  infections  rise. Sophia  Chan  said  the  government  had  been  forced  to  cancel  some  of  its  mask  procurement  orders  as  some  countries  abruptly  imposed  a  mask  embargo.

Govt  decision  on  reopening  schools  by  month  end. The  decision  would  be  made  upon  how  effective  it  would  be  to  protect  students  from  the  virus  infection,  HK's  education  chief  said  on  Wednesday.
Hong  Kong  stocks  plunge  to  new  three-year  low. Hong  Kong  stocks  nosedived  by  over  800  points,  refreshing  the  three-year  low.
Pet  dog  released  from  coronavirus  quarantine  dies. The  authorities  said  the  cause  of  death  couldn’t  be  determined  after  the  owner  declined  to  conduct  an  autopsy.
Coronavirus  —    a  survivor’s  story. Most  patients  who  come  down  with  the  novel  coronavirus  do  recover  but,  for  some,  they  have  to  endure  scars  that’ll  never  heal.

Trade  council:  HK  exports  may  shrink  more  than  2%  this  year. Hong  Kong's  exports  are  likely  to  shrink  by  more  than  the  previously  predicted  2  percent  this  year,  weighed  down  by  the  novel  coronavirus  pandemic.

HK  students  told  to  stay  put  if  they  develop  symptoms  overseas. Health  authorities  advise  students  to  seek  medical  attention  where  they  get  symptoms,  as  throngs  of  returnees  further  strain  city's  medical  system.

Overseas  students  scramble  for  flights  home. Chinese  students  scrambling  to  get  back  home  from  the  United  Kingdom,  as  the  epicenter  of  the  coronavirus  outbreak  has  shifted  from  China  to  Europe.
Mental  aid  for  students  trapped  at  home  urged. The  government  said  on  Tuesday  that  schools  might  not  be  able  to  fully  resume  classes  as  scheduled  on  April  20.
Travel  curb  set  to  foreign  countries. All  international  travelers  face  home  quarantine  or  medical  surveillance.

Hong  Kong's  unemployment  rate  climbs  to  9-year  high. HK's  unemployment  rate  climbed  to  3.7%  for  the  December-to-February  period,  with  consumption  and  tourism-related  sectors  the  hardest  hit.

Jobless  rate  hits  9-year  high  as  pandemic  bites. HK's  unemployment  rate  has  surged  to  a  nine-year  high,  aggravated  by  COVID-19  pandemic  that  has  disrupted  economic  activities  and  dampened  sentiment.
HK's  economic  freedom  remains  despite  current  challenges. Commerce  secretary  says  a  difficult  2019  is  behind  city's  slipping  to  No  2  in  Heritage  Foundation  ranking.

Mandatory  quarantine  for  all  arrivals  in  HK  starting  March  19. The  Hong  Kong  government  issued  a  Red  Outbound  Travel  Alert  on  all  overseas  countries  and  territories  on  Tuesday  evening.

HK:  Returning  student  among  5  new  patients. Health  authorities  have  advised  HK  students  studying  overseas  to  seek  timely  treatment  locally  when  they  develop  symptoms  of  infection.

HK  stocks  recover  slightly  despite  huge  falls  on  Wall  Street. The  benchmark  Hang  Seng  Index  ended  its  four-day  losing  streak  on  Tuesday  to  close  200.16  points,  or  0.87  percent,  higher  at  23,263.73  points.

HK  confident  of  ranking  rebound  after  bested  by  S'pore. HK's  high  degree  of  freedom  is  intact  &  not  be  overwhelmed  by  any  adversity,  the  govt  said  after  the  city  lost  its  world's  freest  economy  title  to  Singapore.

HK  readying  Chapter  11-style  bankruptcy  system. The  government  hoped  to  introduce  a  bill  setting  out  the  new  arrangements  in  early  2021  at  the  next  LegCo  session  after  the  Sept  election,  an  official  said.
TCM  joins  the  fight. Practitioners  say  traditional  Chinese  medicine  has  a  part  to  play  amid  the  COVID-19  pandemic.

Overseas  students  scramble  for  flights  home. Another  trap  is  about  to  be  sprung  on  HK  and  mainland  students  scrambling  to  get  back  home  from  the  UK,  as  the  virus  epicenter  has  shifted  to  Europe.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.87%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  200.16  points,  or  0.87  percent,  to  23,263.73  points.

CUHK  to  test  stool  samples  for  virus  detection. CUHK  researchers  said  they  would  test  the  stool  samples  of  100  people  in  quarantine  centers  in  a  bid  to  find  out  asymptomatic  patients.

Govt  urges  opposition  councilors  to  remove  offensive  notices. The  Home  Affairs  Department  said  it  had  received  numerous  complaints  against  Lee  Man-ho  and  Lao  Ka-hang  for  posting  offensive  notices  outside  their  office.
Hong  Kong  shutdown  a  lesson  to  the  world  in  halting  virus. As  the  world  struggles  with  the  rapid  spread  of  COVID-19,  Hong  Kong  appears  to  be  having  success  controlling  it.

HK  imported  cases  rise  amid  tight  border  control. On  Monday  alone,  the  city  recorded  nine  new  confirmed  cases  —  all  linked  to  overseas  travel  to  Europe,  Africa,  North  America  and  Japan.

Experts  relieve  concern  on  cross-infection  in  evacuation. The  government  said  the  second  batch  of  chartered  flights  will  pick  up  Hong  Kong  residents  stranded  in  the  cities  of  Xiaogan,  Xianning  and  Huangshi.

Cathay  Pacific  loses  HK$2  billion  in  February  due  to  virus. The  monthly  loss  is  for  Cathay  and  full-service  unit  Cathay  Dragon,  Chief  Customer  and  Commercial  Officer  Ronald  Lam  said  in  a  statement  Monday.

HK  frees  HK$500  billion  in  bank  capital  to  lift  economy. The  HKMA  on  Monday  lowered  its  countercyclical  capital  buffer  imposed  on  banks  to  1%  from  2%,  and  also  reduced  its  base  rate  to  0.86%.

Risk  of  local  outbreak  seen  as  7  new  cases  linked  to  foreign  travel. HK  authorities  warned  about  a  second  round  of  coronavirus  outbreak,  after  7  cases  of  infection  were  reported  -  all  linked  to  overseas  travel.

HK  Disneyland  sending  workers  on  leave  to  weather  virus. Already  reeling  from  a  drop  in  visitors  caused  by  unrest  in  HK,  Walt  Disney  Co.’s  local  operations  have  suffered  a  second  blow  with  the  virus  outbreak.

HK  stocks  join  regional  free  fall  as  fresh  US  rate  cut  fails  to  impress. HK  stocks  tumbled  again  on  Monday,  ignoring  a  swifter-than-expected  US  interest-rate  cut  as  concerns  continued  to  mount  over  the  pandemic's  impact.

Sources:  JD.com  hired  banks  for  HK  listing  as  early  as  mid-year. Chinese  e-commerce  retailer  JD.com  Inc  has  hired  Bank  of  America  and  UBS  to  work  on  a  second  listing  in  Hong  Kong,  two  people  with  direct  knowledge  said.
HK  Disneyland  sees  HK$105m  net  loss  from  social  unrest. Attendance  at  the  theme  park  dropped  4  percent  in  2019  to  6.5  million.

Tourism  sector  to  get  HK$400-m  subsidy  as  visitors  decline. The  HK  Tourism  Board  will  roll  out  a  HK$400-m  plan  to  support  the  tourism  industry  battered  by  protests  &  currently  reeling  under  a  coronavirus  outbreak.
Chan:  HK  unemployment  rate  to  hit  nine-year  high. The  unemployment  rate  is  forecast  to  reach  3.6  percent,  the  highest  since  June  2011,  based  on  a  survey  of  economists.

2nd  batch  of  chartered  flights  to  Hubei  earliest  on  March  24. The  second  batch  of  flights  will  mainly  pick  up  Hong  Kong  residents  stranded  because  of  the  coronavirus  in  the  cities  of  Xiaogan,  Xianning  and  Huangshi.

HK  govt  to  charge  fees  to  discourage  accommodation  abuse. The  HK  govt  will  charge  each  occupant  HK$200  a  day  for  staying  in  temporary  accommodation  to  crack  down  on  the  abuse  of  quarantine  centers.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  4.03%  lower  after  Fed  rate  cut. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  969.34  points,  or  4.03  percent,  to  23,063.57  points  on  Monday.
HK-based  MD  offers  classes  on  virus  safety. In  this  new  series,  we  share  stories  and  experiences  showing  how  expats  are  dealing  with  the  novel  coronavirus  pneumonia  outbreak.
Commissioner  values  front-line  communication. Chris  Tang  Ping-keung  plans  to  bring  Asia's  finest  back  to  its  former  glory.
HK  tightens  border  control  to  contain  virus. The  SAR  govt  issued  “red”  outbound  travel  alerts  for  Ireland,  UK  and  US.
